steps.content: See if the dog has pricked ears. Shibas have small, perked up ears that resemble that of a wolf. The ears are triangular in shape and are angled forward atop the dog's head. steps.content: Notice a brushy and curly tail. Most Shiba Inu have curled tails, but the dog may have a less common tail type called a sickle tail. steps.content: Pay attention to the dog's eye color. The AKC standards list that the eyes of a Shiba Inu should be dark brown in color with black rims. steps.content: Look at the muzzle of the dog. A Shiba's muzzle should be round and firm with a black nose. The jawline is strong and gives the dog a powerful expression. steps.title: Analyze the texture of the dog's coat.
steps.content: Analyze the texture of the dog's coat. Shiba Inu have thick double coats. Their fur is moderately straight and short in length. steps.title: Recognize the dog's fur color.
steps.content: Recognize the dog's fur color. Shiba Inu have four possible coat colors: red, black and tan, cream, and sesame. Red is the most commonly seen coloring of a Shiba Inu. It is the preferred coat color of the AKC for this breed. Black and tan Shiba Inu are also popular. Cream Shiba Inu are frowned upon by the AKC and go against the breed standards. steps.content: Look for the urajiro markings. This Japanese word refers to a Shiba Inu's white marks. These appear on places such as the face, neck, stomach, legs, and tail.
